Award.AwardTitle: Towards Energy Efficiency Through Low-DO Nitrification: Extending our Knowledge of Ammonia-Oxidizing Organisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1435661
Noguera

Towards Energy Efficiency Through Low-DO Nitrification: Extending our Knowledge of Ammonia-Oxidizing Organisms

In wastewater treatment activated sludge is a common process. Activated sludge is the single largest energy user because of the amount of oxygen that is needed to maintain aerobic (oxygen rich) conditions. This proposal seeks to identify and characterize the novel organisms that perform ammonia oxidation under low-DO conditions and thereby reducing the cost of the process. The hypothesis is that unrecognized ammonia-oxidizing organisms are likely responsible for nitrification in low-dissolved oxygen activated sludge systems. If this study is successful it will result in a significant reduction in energy costs for many wastewater treatment plants in the Nation. The project will also allow the PIs to continue mentoring high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, and will fund the training of two PhD students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering.

Technically, the project is divided into three tasks which include; 1) screening a collection of pure cultures isolated from a lab-scale reactor performing efficient nitrification, 2) focused on the identification of the abundant ammonia-oxidizing organisms in lab-scale reactors, and 3) conduct kinetic experiments to characterize the microbial communities in pilot-scale reactors coupling and treating primary effluent from a full scale wastewater treatment plant. The effective coupling of enhanced biological phosphorus removal and low-dissolved oxygen nitrification will be a transformative development, since aeration for nutrient removal can account for nearly half of the energy use. This project will enable development of new technologies that contribute to the wastewater industry's overarching goals of achieving energy neutrality and shifting the focus from waste treatment to resource recovery facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main hypothesis in this project was that heretofore unrecognized ammonia-oxidizing prokaryotes were the main organisms responsible for nitrification in activated sludge reactors operated with low dissolved oxygen (DO < 0.2 mg/L). To evaluate this hypothesis, we operated lab-scale and pilot-scale biological nutrient removal reactors, analyzed their performance over a period of three years, and evaluated the microbial communities that were enriched in the reactors.  

One of the outcomes of this study was the identification of organisms performing complete ammonia oxidization (comammox) to nitrate in the lab-scale and pilot-scale reactors. A draft genome of a strain of Nitrospira nitrosa was assembled from metagenomic data collected from the lab-scale reactor. We also detected the presence of an ammonia oxidizing bacterium (AOB) belonging to the Nitrosomonas genus, but sufficiently different in the sequence of the ammonia monooxygenase marker gene (amoA) that we believe it has eluded quantification in earlier studies. A draft genome for this Nitrosomonas sp. was assembled from the metagenomic data collected from the lab-scale reactor. Further studies are needed to determine whether this is a novel species within the genus Nitrosomonas. We also ruled out the activity of ammonia oxidizing archaea (AOA) or heterotrophic nitrifiers in the lab-scale and pilot scale reactors.

Another important outcome of this project was the demonstration that it is possible to operate activated sludge plants to simultaneously achieve efficient phosphorus and nitrogen removal with minimum aeration. These processes were stable not only under controlled laboratory conditions but also in pilot-scale reactors operated at the Nine Springs wastewater treatment plant (Madison, WI). The process appears to be more sensitive to low temperature conditions, and further investigation is needed to develop a robust strategy for low-DO nitrification at full-scale conditions. Regarding the removal of phosphorus, we identified a clade of Accumulibacter phosphatis that is enriched under cyclic anaerobic/low-DO conditions (Clade IC). A draft genome of this organism was assembled from the lab-scale reactor. Based on kinetic experiments and metagenomic information, we hypothesize that this Accumulibacter strain is well adapted to the simultaneous use of oxygen and nitrate as electron acceptors under low DO conditions.

Regarding broader impacts, this project allowed us to provide opportunities for the training of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. The discoveries in this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through publications in peer reviewed journals, conference presentations, and students’ theses. The new knowledge created in this project has also been used for discussion in courses related to biological wastewater treatment processes.
